title: The Survival of the Chinese Jews: The Jewish Community of Kaifeng
keyPoints: Foundational work on Kaifeng Jewish history; analysis of Yuan Dynasty policies; documentation of stone inscriptions
keyHypotheses: Chinese governmental tolerance enabled Jewish survival for over 1000 years
strengths: Comprehensive primary source analysis; established academic framework
weaknesses: Limited analysis of political participation mechanisms
citation: Leslie, D.D. (1972). The Survival of the Chinese Jews: The Jewish Community of Kaifeng. Leiden: E.J. Brill.
notes: Seminal work - all subsequent scholarship builds on this foundation

title: The Kaifeng Jews: A Reconsideration of Acculturation and Assimilation in a Comparative Perspective
keyPoints: Comparative analysis with Muslim minorities; role of Chinese religious pluralism; permeable boundaries of Chinese religion
keyHypotheses: Chinese religious milieu was uniquely conducive to Jewish acculturation compared to other societies
weaknesses: Limited primary source material from Chinese archives
citation: Sharot, S. (2007). The Kaifeng Jews: A Reconsideration of Acculturation and Assimilation in a Comparative Perspective. Jewish Social Studies, 13(2), 179-203.
notes: Key theoretical work on mechanisms of Jewish integration

title: Chinese Policy Toward Kaifeng Jews
journal: The Image of Jews in Contemporary China
keyPoints: 1489 stele three-point covenant; distinction between pre-1840 and post-1840 Jews; PRC policies since 1950s
keyHypotheses: Chinese policy of respecting religion while promoting integration enabled Jewish political participation
strengths: Leading expert perspective; access to Chinese sources; contemporary policy analysis
weaknesses: Limited by current Chinese academic restrictions
citation: Xu, X. (2019). Chinese Policy Toward Kaifeng Jews. In The Image of Jews in Contemporary China (pp. 54-71). Academic Studies Press.
notes: Most authoritative contemporary analysis by leading Chinese scholar

title: Chinese Jews
keyPoints: Three-part comprehensive documentation; letters and reports; Chinese and Hebrew documents; genealogical information
keyHypotheses: Jewish community maintained distinct identity while integrating into Chinese society
strengths: Extensive primary source collection; comprehensive documentation
weaknesses: Pre-modern historical bias; limited theoretical framework
citation: White, W.C. (1942). Chinese Jews. University of Toronto Press.
notes: Classic reference work - reprinted 1966 by Paragon Book Reprint Corporation

title: The Jews of China and their Contribution to the Establishment of the Jewish National Home in Palestine in the First Half of the Twentieth Century
keyPoints: Political connections between Chinese Jews and Zionist movement; international networks; contribution to Jewish nationalism
keyHypotheses: Chinese Jews maintained political connections beyond China contributing to global Jewish political movements
strengths: Unique international perspective; documents transnational political networks
weaknesses: Limited focus on domestic Chinese political participation
citation: Katz, Y. (2010). The Jews of China and their Contribution to the Establishment of the Jewish National Home in Palestine in the First Half of the Twentieth Century. Middle Eastern Studies, 46(4), 543-554.
notes: Demonstrates international political engagement of Chinese Jews

title: The Jews of Kaifeng, China: History, Culture, and Religion (review)
keyPoints: Critical review of Xu Xin's work; assessment of existing scholarship; gaps in historical documentation
keyHypotheses: Existing scholarship has addressed historical gaps but pseudo-history claims persist
strengths: Critical scholarly assessment; identifies research needs
citation: Pollak, M. (2005). The Jews of Kaifeng, China: History, Culture, and Religion (review). Shofar, 23(3), 206-209.
notes: Important scholarly critique highlighting research gaps

title: The K'aifeng Jew Chao Ying-ch'eng and His Family
keyPoints: Detailed family study of specific Kaifeng Jewish official; bureaucratic service documentation; social integration patterns
keyHypotheses: Individual Jewish families achieved significant integration into Chinese bureaucratic system
strengths: Detailed case study methodology; specific evidence of political participation
citation: Leslie, D. (1967). The K'aifeng Jew Chao Ying-ch'eng and His Family. T'oung Pao, 53(1), 147-183.
notes: Provides concrete evidence of Jewish political participation in Chinese government

title: K'aifeng Jews Revisited: Sinification as Affirmation of Identity
keyPoints: Sinification process as identity preservation; cultural adaptation strategies; religion and identity markers
keyHypotheses: Sinification was a deliberate strategy for identity preservation rather than assimilation
strengths: Novel theoretical perspective; challenges assimilation narratives
weaknesses: Limited political analysis; focus primarily cultural
citation: Eber, I. (1993). K'aifeng Jews Revisited: Sinification as Affirmation of Identity. Monumenta Serica, 41, 275-291.
notes: Important reconceptualization of Chinese Jewish cultural strategies

title: Where Is the Home: Kaifeng Jews Descendants on the Road of Return
journal: Asian Journal of Social Science Studies
keyPoints: Contemporary identity negotiation; PRC ethnic classification impact; aliyah motivations; Israeli integration challenges
keyHypotheses: Kaifeng Jewish identity persists despite official erasure and creates complex citizenship questions
strengths: Contemporary fieldwork; interviews with community members; policy analysis
weaknesses: Limited sample size; potential bias in self-selected interview subjects
citation: Wu, J. (2022). Where Is the Home: Kaifeng Jews Descendants on the Road of Return. Asian Journal of Social Science Studies, 7(9), 63-78.
notes: Most recent academic study with direct community access

title: After a thousand years, China's Kaifeng Jews have almost, but not quite, disappeared
keyPoints: CCP fear of smallest religious community; synagogue destruction; scripture removal; non-recognition of religion and ethnicity
keyHypotheses: CCP actively seeks to erase Jewish identity due to perceived political threat
strengths: Current policy documentation; contemporary political analysis
weaknesses: Journalistic rather than academic source; limited primary source access
citation: Graceffo, A. (2024). After a thousand years, China's Kaifeng Jews have almost, but not quite, disappeared. MercatorNet.
notes: Recent documentation of government suppression policies

title: China and Ashkenazic Jewry: transcultural encounters
keyPoints: Transcultural encounters; Ashkenazic Jewish perspectives; contemporary Chinese-Jewish relations
keyHypotheses: Contemporary Chinese-Jewish relations reflect broader transcultural dynamics beyond Kaifeng community
strengths: Latest scholarly perspective; international comparative approach
weaknesses: Paywall access limits detailed analysis; recently published
citation: Wang, Y. (2025). China and Ashkenazic Jewry: transcultural encounters. Modern Chinese Studies, doi: 10.1080/14725886.2024.2431911.
notes: Most recent academic publication on Chinese-Jewish relations

title: Chinese Philo-Semitism: Why China Admires the Jewish People
journal: University of New Hampshire Student Research
keyPoints: Contemporary Chinese attitudes toward Jews; philo-semitic discourse; education and success narratives; Holocaust awareness
keyHypotheses: Modern Chinese philo-semitism reflects admiration for perceived Jewish success and education
strengths: Contemporary social research; personal observation; cultural analysis
weaknesses: Student research level; limited scope; non-peer reviewed
citation: Haime, J. (2020). Chinese Philo-Semitism: Why China Admires the Jewish People. University of New Hampshire Student Research Projects, 26.
notes: Provides contemporary Chinese perspective on Jewish identity

title: China's Ambivalent Attitude Towards Judaism
keyPoints: Government ambivalence; historical tolerance vs. contemporary suppression; policy contradictions
keyHypotheses: Chinese government maintains ambivalent approach balancing historical precedent with contemporary security concerns
strengths: Policy analysis; institutional perspective; contemporary focus
weaknesses: Think tank rather than academic source; limited primary source access
citation: Segev, H. (2018). China's Ambivalent Attitude Towards Judaism. Middle East Institute.
notes: Institutional analysis of contemporary Chinese Jewish policy

title: Sukkot and Mid-Autumn Festivals in Kaifeng: Conundrums at the Crossroads of Sino-Judaic Cultural Identity
journal: The Image of Jews in Contemporary China
keyPoints: Religious syncretism; festival overlap; cultural identity negotiation; Sino-Judaic practices
keyHypotheses: Religious syncretism enabled Jewish survival while creating unique Sino-Judaic cultural forms
strengths: Religious studies expertise; cultural analysis; syncretism focus
weaknesses: Limited political analysis; primarily cultural focus
citation: Bernstein, M.Y. (2019). Sukkot and Mid-Autumn Festivals in Kaifeng: Conundrums at the Crossroads of Sino-Judaic Cultural Identity. In The Image of Jews in Contemporary China (pp. 72-98). Academic Studies Press.
notes: Detailed analysis of religious-cultural adaptation mechanisms

title: Who Are the Kaifeng Jews — and Why Is China 'Cracking Down' on Them?
keyPoints: Government crackdown documentation; community suppression; international attention; policy shift under Xi Jinping
keyHypotheses: Chinese government views Kaifeng Jews as potential political threat requiring suppression
strengths: Contemporary documentation; international media attention; policy timing analysis
weaknesses: Journalistic source; limited academic rigor; potential bias
citation: Kestenbaum, S. (2016). Who Are the Kaifeng Jews — and Why Is China 'Cracking Down' on Them? Forward.
notes: Documents shift from tolerance to suppression under current leadership

title: CCP is Silencing Tiny Community of Kaifeng Jews
keyPoints: Religious freedom violations; community silencing; surveillance; cultural suppression; international attention
keyHypotheses: CCP systematic campaign to eliminate Jewish identity as part of broader religious suppression
strengths: Human rights documentation; contemporary evidence; international perspective
weaknesses: Advocacy publication bias; limited academic methodology
citation: Joplin, T. (2020). CCP is Silencing Tiny Community of Kaifeng Jews. Bitter Winter.
notes: Documents human rights violations and religious freedom restrictions
